Signs and symptoms: Blood infection: Fever, chills, vomiting, confusion Urinary tract infection: bloody urine, cloudy urine Pneumonia: Fever, chills, coughing
Treatment: Supportive care

Infectious agent: Actinomyces israelii, Actinomyces gerencseriae and Propionibacterium propionicus
Signs and symptoms: Painful abscesses
Treatment: Penicillin, doxycycline, and sulfonamides

Signs and symptoms: high fever that lasts 4–6 days pharyngitis (sore throat) conjunctivitis (inflamed eyes, usually without pus formation like pink eye) enlargement of the lymph nodes of the neck headache, malaise, and weakness Incubation period of 5–9 days
Diagnosis: Antigen detection, polymerase chain reaction assay, virus isolation, and serology
Treatment: Most infections are mild and require no therapy or only symptomatic treatment.

Signs and symptoms: Hemolymphatic phase: Fever, lymphadenopathy Neurological phase: Sleep disorders, neurological symptoms, psychiatric symptoms
Diagnosis: Identification of trypanosomes in a sample by microscopic examination
Treatment: Fexinidazole by mouth or pentamidine by injection for T. b. gambiense. Suramin by injection is used for T. b. rhodesiense

Signs and symptoms: Opportunistic infections
Diagnosis: Antibody test, p24 antigen test, PCR
Treatment: Treatment is typically a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) plus two nucleoside analog reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs)

Signs and symptoms: Most are asymptomatic.
Treatment: Those with symptoms require treatment with an amoebicidal tissue-active agent and a luminal cysticidal agent. Individuals that are asymptomatic only need a luminal cysticidal agent.

Signs and symptoms: Fever, leukopenia, abnormally elevated levels of liver enzymes
Diagnosis: indirect immunofluorescence antibody assay for IgG
Treatment: Tetracycline drugs (including tetracycline, chlortetracycline, oxytetracycline, rolitetracycline, doxycycline, and minocycline) and imidocarb

Signs and symptoms: Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weakness, fever, central nervous system (CNS) symptoms
Treatment: Albendazole

Signs and symptoms: Severe abdominal pain, malnutrition, and vomiting
Treatment: Albendazole

Signs and symptoms: boil-like skin lesion that eventually forms an ulcer with a black center (eschar)
Treatment: Large doses of intravenous and oral antibiotics, such as fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin), doxycycline, erythromycin, vancomycin, or penicillin

Signs and symptoms: Head and neck infections, pharyngitis, and sinusitis
Diagnosis: Culture in human blood agar plates
Treatment: erythromycin (proposed as the first-line drug), clindamycin, gentamicin, and cephalosporins

Signs and symptoms: Migrating larvae, intestinal blockage, and bowel obstruction
Treatment: Albendazole, mebendazole, levamisole and pyrantel pamoate

Signs and symptoms: Hemoptysis, chest pain
Diagnosis: Chest X-ray and CT,  microscopy by silver stains
Treatment: Voriconazole and liposomal amphotericin B in combination with surgical debridement

Signs and symptoms: Diarrhoea, followed by nausea, vomiting, fever, malaise and abdominal pain
Diagnosis: Electron microscopy, enzyme-immunoassay (ELISA), immunofluorescence, and polymerase chain reaction
Treatment: Supportive care

Signs and symptoms: Fever and hemolytic anemia
Treatment: Atovaquone and azithromycin. In life-threatening cases, exchange transfusion is performed.

Signs and symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
Treatment: Vancomycin

Signs and symptoms: neck stiffness, sudden high fever, and altered mental status
Diagnosis: Lumbar puncture (contraindicated if there is a mass in the brain or the intracranial pressure is elevated), CT or MRI
Treatment: Antibiotics

Signs and symptoms: Fever, rigors, cough, and runny nose, chest pain
Diagnosis: Sputum Gram stain and culture, Chest radiography
Treatment: Antibiotics

Signs and symptoms: Increased vaginal discharge that usually smells like fish
Treatment: Metronidazole or clindamycin

Signs and symptoms: Intermittent diarrhea, constipation, vomiting, abdominal pain, anorexia, weight loss, headache, colitis, and marked fluid loss
Diagnosis: microscopic examination of stools, or colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy
Treatment: Tetracycline, metronidazole or iodoquinol

Signs and symptoms: Carrión's disease, trench fever, cat-scratch disease, bacillary angiomatosis, peliosis hepatis, chronic bacteremia, endocarditis, chronic lymphadenopathy, and neurological disorders
Treatment: Antibiotics

Signs and symptoms: formation of nodules on the scalp, moustache and pubic hair
Treatment: Antifungal shampoos such as pyrithione zinc, formaldehyde and salicylic acid

Signs and symptoms: abdominal pain, itching, usually anal itching, constipation, diarrhea, watery or loose stool
Diagnosis: microscopic examination of a chemically preserved stool specimen
Treatment: Lack of scientific study to support the efficacy of any particular treatment

Signs and symptoms: fever, chills, arthralgia (joint pain), myalgia (muscle pain), headache, and a nonproductive cough
Treatment: Itraconazole or ketoconazole

Infectious agent: Clostridium botulinum; Note: Botulism is not an infection by Clostridium botulinum but caused by the intake of botulinum toxin.
Signs and symptoms: Double vision, drooping of both eyelids, loss of facial expression and swallowing problems
Treatment: Botulism antitoxin and supportive care

Signs and symptoms: fevers, sweating (often with characteristic foul, moldy smell sometimes likened to wet hay), and migratory arthralgia and myalgia (joint and muscle pain)
Treatment: Tetracyclines, rifampicin, and the aminoglycosides streptomycin and gentamicin

Signs and symptoms: Chills, malaise, high fever, muscle cramps, seizures
Treatment: Aminoglycosides such as streptomycin and gentamicin, tetracyclines (especially doxycycline), and the fluoroquinolone ciprofloxacin

Infectious agent: usually Burkholderia cepacia and other Burkholderia species

Signs and symptoms: Swollen bump
Treatment: The most widely used antibiotic regimen is once daily oral rifampicin plus twice daily oral clarithromycin.

Signs and symptoms: Vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain
Fever, headache, and myalgia, followed by diarrhea
Treatment: Erythromycin can be used in children, and tetracycline in adults.

Infectious agent: usually Candida albicans and other Candida species
Signs and symptoms: Redness, itching, and discomfort
Diagnosis: In oral candidiasis, simply inspecting the person's mouth for white patches and irritation may make the diagnosis. Symptoms of vaginal candidiasis are vaginal itching or soreness, pain during sexual intercourse
Treatment: Antifungal medications

Infectious agent: Intestinal disease by Capillaria philippinensis, hepatic disease by Capillaria hepatica and pulmonary disease by Capillaria aerophila

Signs and symptoms: Tooth pain, difficulty eating, discoloration, tooth loss
Fever, pale appearance, malaise, painless liver enlargement, jaundice, enlarged lymph nodes, and enlarged spleen
Diagnosis: Peripheral blood smear with Giemsa stain, Columbia blood agar cultures, immunoblot, indirect immunofluorescence, and PCR
Treatment: Fluoroquinolones (such as ciprofloxacin) or chloramphenicol in adults and chloramphenicol plus beta-lactams in children are the antibiotic regimens of choice during the acute phase of Carrion's disease.

Signs and symptoms: Malaise, decreased appetite, and aches
Treatment: Azithromycin

Infectious agent: usually Group A Streptococcus and Staphylococcus
Signs and symptoms: An area that is red, hot, and painful
Treatment: Penicillinase-resistant semisynthetic penicillin or a first-generation cephalosporin

Signs and symptoms: Fever, malaise, headache, and enlargement of the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes
Diagnosis: Microscopic examination of fresh anticoagulated blood, or its buffy coat, for motile parasites; or by preparation of thin and thick blood smears stained with Giemsa, for direct visualization of parasites
Treatment: Benznidazole and nifurtimox (though benznidazole is the only drug available in most of Latin America)

Signs and symptoms: Painful sores on the genitalia
Treatment: The CDC recommendation is either a single oral dose (1 gram) of azithromycin, a single IM dose (250 mg) of ceftriaxone, oral (500 mg) of erythromycin three times a day for seven days, or oral (500 mg) of ciprofloxacin twice a day for three days.

Signs and symptoms: nausea, loss of appetite, aching muscles, and headache, followed by the characteristic rash or oral sores, malaise, and a low-grade fever
Diagnosis: The diagnosis of chickenpox is primarily based on the signs and symptoms, with typical early symptoms followed by a characteristic rash. Confirmation of the diagnosis is by examination of the fluid within the vesicles of the rash, or by testing blood for evidence of an acute immunologic response.
Treatment: Aciclovir

Signs and symptoms: sudden onset, combining high fever, joint pain, and rash
Diagnosis: Laboratory criteria include a decreased lymphocyte count consistent with viremia. However a definitive laboratory diagnosis can be accomplished through viral isolation, RT-PCR, or serological diagnosis.
Treatment: Supportive care

Signs and symptoms: In women, those who have an asymptomatic infection that is not detected by their doctor, approximately half will develop pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), In men, painful or burning sensation when urinating
Diagnosis: Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT), such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR), transcription mediated amplification (TMA), and the DNA strand displacement amplification (SDA)
Treatment: azithromycin, doxycycline, erythromycin, levofloxacin or ofloxacin

Common name: Chlamydophila pneumoniae infection (Taiwan acute respiratory agent or TWAR)

Signs and symptoms: Profuse diarrhea and vomiting of clear fluid
Diagnosis: A rapid dipstick test is available.
Treatment: oral rehydration therapy (ORT)

Signs and symptoms: Usually, the infection slowly spreads to the surrounding tissue while still remaining localized to the area around the original wound.
Treatment: Itraconazole, an antifungal azole, is given orally, with or without flucytosine.

Signs and symptoms: diarrhea, recent antibiotic exposure, abdominal pain, fever, and a distinctive foul odor
Diagnosis: Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy, cytotoxicity assay, toxin ELISA
Treatment: Vancomycin or fidaxomicin by mouth

Common name: Common cold (Acute viral rhinopharyngitis; Acute coryza)
Signs and symptoms: Cough, runny nose, sneezing, nasal congestion, and a sore throa
Treatment: Supportive care

Signs and symptoms: Fever, cough, loss of taste and smell
Fever, headache, sore throat, gastrointestinal distress, extreme fatigue as well as chest and muscle pain
Diagnosis: Enterovirus infection is diagnosed mainly via serological tests such as ELISA and from cell culture.
Treatment: There is no well-accepted treatment for the Coxsackie B group of viruses.

Signs and symptoms: Memory loss, behavioral changes, poor coordination
Cough, shortness of breath, chest pain and fever
Diagnosis: India ink of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
Treatment: Intravenous Amphotericin B combined with flucytosine by mouth

Signs and symptoms: Gastrointestinal and respiratory symptoms

Infectious agent: usually Ancylostoma braziliense; multiple other parasites

Signs and symptoms: Fatigue, swollen glands, fever, sore throat, muscle aches
Treatment: Cidofovir, foscarnet, ganciclovir, valganciclovir

Infectious agent: Dengue viruses (DEN-1, DEN-2, DEN-3 and DEN-4) – Flaviviruses
Signs and symptoms: Sudden-onset fever, headache, muscle and joint pains, and a rash
Treatment: Treatment depends on the symptoms.

Signs and symptoms: fever of 38 °C (100.4 °F) or above; chills; fatigue; bluish skin coloration (cyanosis); sore throat; hoarseness; cough; headache; difficulty swallowing; painful swallowing; difficulty breathing; rapid breathing; foul-smelling and bloodstained nasal discharge; and lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis: Laboratory criteria Isolation of C. diphtheriae culture Histopathologic diagnosis Toxin demonstration  In vivo tests (guinea pig inoculation) In vitro test: Elek's gel precipitation test, PCR, ELISA, ICA Clinical criteria  URT illness with sore throat Low-grade fever An adherent, dense, grey pseudomembrane covering the posterior aspect of the pharynx
Treatment: Metronidazole, Erythromycin, Procaine penicillin G

Signs and symptoms: Burning pain, blister from which worm emerges
High fever, muscle pain, altered mental status, headache, meningeal irritation, photophobia, and seizures
Treatment: Corticosteroids, anticonvulsants, and supportive measures (treating symptoms)

Signs and symptoms: Flu-like symptoms, severe internal and external bleeding
Anal itching that gets worse at night, disturbed sleep
Severe insomnia followed by dementia, hallucinations, and death
Diarrhea, vomiting, and fever
Treatment: Supportive care

Infectious agent: usually Clostridium perfringens; other Clostridium species
Signs and symptoms: Discoloration, large black blisters, foul odor, pain and numbness
Symptoms vary from none to severe diarrhea with poor absorption of nutrients.
Diagnosis: Detection of antigens on the surface of organisms in stool
Treatment: Treatment is not always necessary. If medications are needed, a nitroimidazole medication is used such as metronidazole, tinidazole, secnidazole or ornidazole.

Signs and symptoms: Swelling, itching, pain, and the formation of pus
Treatment: Ceftriaxone by injection and azithromycin by mouth

Signs and symptoms: impetigo, cellulitis, and erysipelas – infections of the skin which can be complicated by necrotizing fasciitis – skin, fascia and muscle strep throat AKA strep pharyngitis – pharynx
Treatment: Penicillin

Infectious agent: Enteroviruses, mainly Coxsackie A virus and enterovirus 71 (EV71)
Signs and symptoms: Fever, rash, small blisters
Stomach ulcers

Infectious agent: Escherichia coli O157:H7, O111 and O104:H4
Herpes simplex virus 1 and 2 (HSV-1 and HSV-2)
Signs and symptoms: Blisters on genitalia and lips
Warts

Infectious agent: unknown; evidence supports that it is infectious

Signs and symptoms: Emotional disturbance, tremors, loss of coordination
Numbness, small nodules, deformation of extremities

Infectious agent: Borrelia burgdorferi, Borrelia garinii, and Borrelia afzelii

Signs and symptoms: Severe swelling of extremities, thickened skin
Fever, chills, sweating
Fever, cough, runny nose, red rash
Swelling and inflammation of parotid glands

Infectious agent: numerous species of bacteria (Actinomycetoma) and fungi (Eumycetoma)

Signs and symptoms: Boil with larva inside

Infectious agent: most commonly Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae
usually Nocardia asteroides and other Nocardia species
usually Paragonimus westermani and other Paragonimus species

Signs and symptoms: Itching, nits attached to hair
Severe coughing fits ending in gasps

Infectious agent: Borrelia hermsii, Borrelia recurrentis, and other Borrelia species
usually Epidermophyton floccosum, Trichophyton rubrum, and Trichophyton mentagrophytes
Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica, serovar typhi
